unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning that long-awaited trip to Goa, are you? Awesome! But before you pack your sunscreen and shades, let's talk about something less glamorous but equally crucial: keeping track of your travel identifiers. I know, I know, it sounds boring, but trust me, a little bit of organization can save you from a whole lot of stress.
normalised: Okay, so you're planning that long-awaited trip to Goa, are you? Awesome! But before you pack your sunscreen and shades, let's talk about something less glamorous but equally crucial: keeping track of your travel identifiers. I know, I know, it sounds boring, but trust me, a little bit of organization can save you from a whole lot of stress.

unnormalised: First up, your PNR number. This 6-digit code, like "PNR: ZXCV12," is your lifeline for flight and train bookings. Keep it handy; you’ll need it for check-in, status updates, and pretty much everything else. Screenshot it, write it down, memorize it – whatever works for you! Don't rely solely on remembering it!
normalised: First up, your P-N-R number. This six-digit code, like "P-N-R: Z-X-C-V-one-two," is your lifeline for flight and train bookings. Keep it handy; you’ll need it for check-in, status updates, and pretty much everything else. Screenshot it, write it down, memorize it – whatever works for you! Don't rely solely on remembering it!

unnormalised: Then there's your ticket number, often a 13-digit sequence like "Ticket No: 1234567890123". Airlines use this to identify your specific ticket. It's usually printed on your e-ticket and boarding pass. Keep a digital copy AND a printed one. Trust me, phone batteries die at the worst possible moments.
normalised: Then there's your ticket number, often a thirteen-digit sequence like "Ticket No: one-two-three-four-five-six-seven-eight-nine-zero-one-two-three". Airlines use this to identify your specific ticket. It's usually printed on your e-ticket and boarding pass. Keep a digital copy and a printed one. Trust me, phone batteries die at the worst possible moments.

unnormalised: Hotel bookings come with their own set of identifiers. Your confirmation number, perhaps resembling "Confirmation: ABC-DEF-123," is vital. Without it, checking in could become a real hassle. Always double-check you have this before heading to the hotel reception.
normalised: Hotel bookings come with their own set of identifiers. Your confirmation number, perhaps resembling "Confirmation: A-B-C hyphen D-E-F hyphen one-two-three," is vital. Without it, checking in could become a real hassle. Always double-check you have this before heading to the hotel reception.

unnormalised: Speaking of hotels, remember to note down the complete address and contact number of your accommodation. Having a physical address like “Hotel Paradise, Calangute Beach, Goa, 403516” is incredibly helpful, especially if you’re relying on auto-rickshaws or taxis to get around. Don't just assume your driver knows exactly where it is.
normalised: Speaking of hotels, remember to note down the complete address and contact number of your accommodation. Having a physical address like “Hotel Paradise, Calangute Beach, Goa, four zero three five one six” is incredibly helpful, especially if you’re relying on auto-rickshaws or taxis to get around. Don't just assume your driver knows exactly where it is.

unnormalised: For international travel, your passport number, such as “Passport No: AB1234567”, is obviously indispensable. Make a photocopy of your passport's information page and keep it separate from your actual passport. This can be a lifesaver if your passport gets lost or stolen. Also important, expiry date. Imagine turning up at the airport only to be told your passport is expired!
normalised: For international travel, your passport number, such as “Passport No: A-B-one-two-three-four-five-six-seven”, is obviously indispensable. Make a photocopy of your passport's information page and keep it separate from your actual passport. This can be a lifesaver if your passport gets lost or stolen. Also important, expiry date. Imagine turning up at the airport only to be told your passport is expired!

unnormalised: Visas, if required, have their own unique reference numbers. Note down the visa number; it is usually printed on the visa sticker in your passport.
normalised: Visas, if required, have their own unique reference numbers. Note down the visa number; it is usually printed on the visa sticker in your passport.

unnormalised: Travel insurance policies also generate policy numbers like "Policy No: TI-2024-07-15-1234". This is crucial in case of emergencies. Save the insurance company's contact number and policy details on your phone and share them with a family member back home.
normalised: Travel insurance policies also generate policy numbers like "Policy No: T-I hyphen two thousand and twenty four hyphen zero seven hyphen one five hyphen one-two-three-four". This is crucial in case of emergencies. Save the insurance company's contact number and policy details on your phone and share them with a family member back home.

unnormalised: If you're driving in Goa (or anywhere else), ensure you have your driver's license number readily available: "License No: DL-123456789012345". Some car rental companies might need a copy, so be prepared.
normalised: If you're driving in Goa (or anywhere else), ensure you have your driver's license number readily available: "License No: D-L hyphen one-two-three-four-five-six-seven-eight-nine-zero-one-two-three-four-five". Some car rental companies might need a copy, so be prepared.

unnormalised: Keep a scanned copy of all these important documents in a secure cloud storage account (like Google Drive or Dropbox). This provides a backup if you lose physical copies or your phone.
normalised: Keep a scanned copy of all these important documents in a secure cloud storage account (like Google Drive or Dropbox). This provides a backup if you lose physical copies or your phone.

unnormalised: So, there you have it. A few extra minutes of preparation now can save you from potential headaches during your Goan getaway. Happy travels, and remember to have fun! And don't forget to try the vindaloo!
normalised: So, there you have it. A few extra minutes of preparation now can save you from potential headaches during your Goan getaway. Happy travels, and remember to have fun! And don't forget to try the vindaloo!
